bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Louis Johnson, August 3, 1942

div1.p: Hench is excited that Johnson might be able to interest the U.S. State Department in his plan to memorialize Camp Lazear. He feels that this would be an excellent and real opportunity to foster Pan-American solidarity. Hench estimates it would cost about $25,000 to do all he has planned.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Louis Johnson, August 3, 1942
div1.opener:
August 3, 1942
Col. Louis Johnson
Clarksburg
West Virginia
My dear Col. Johnson:
div1.p:
I do not want you to think I was ungrateful for the interest you
expressed in my yellow fever historical venture. Just after seeing you I got some
preliminary orders and I am now leaving this Thursday for active duty with the Army
Medical Corps. In the rush of trying to get many things done before leaving, I have
been unable to send you a synopsis of my investigations in Cuba. I do have a carbon
copy of the formal report which I gave His Excellency Domingo Ramas, Minister of
Defense of Cuba. The original of this copy he filed in the library of the Finlay
Institute. It is profusely illustrated with photostatic documents and photographs.
My own carbon copy does not have a complete set of photographs and documentary
evidence, nor have I had time to have them made so far.

Because I am so delighted with your interest and with your suggestion
that you might be able to interest the State Department in our plan to memorialize
Camp Lazear, I shall try as soon as my army work permits, to make a shorter synopsis
of this report, to have the appropriate photographs printed and send it to you. The
Cuban Government and especially the Cuban medical profession are rather incensed with
the attitude the American Government and American medical profession have taken toward
Doctor Finlay, whom they consider their supreme medical genius and the real dis-
coverer of the cause of yellow fever. The older school of thought in Cuba believes
that Walter Reed and his associates merely confirmed what Findlay had already proven
(and not merely correctly theorized). The newer generation of Cuban physicians is
anxious to heal the breach and I know if the American Government and medical profession
would make the kindly gesture of helping to memorialize the remains of Camp Lazear
and help to donate and dedicate a little Cuban-American medical museum to the glory
of the Cubans, Doctor Finlay and his associates and the American army Yellow Fever
Commission that this breach would be healed to the mutual satisfaction of all concerned.
In my opinion this is a very excellent and real opportunity to foster Pan-American
solidarity. The president of Cuba informally promised that if my associates and I
could carry out such a venture, the government would make the dedication of Camp Lazear
and of the little memorial museum a governmental affair.

I do not know how much this little museum would cost. My own plans
are rather modest. I think $25,000 would do all I had planned. This would purchase
the remains of Camp Lazear, the remains of Walter Reed's experimental building number 1
which still is there and which we discovered, and build a little Cuban style museum
to house the remains of building number 1 and on the surrounding walls to display
Col. Louis Johnson
2
August 3, 1942
certain souvenirs of Finlay and the American Army Yellow Fever Commission, which
I have collected. Doctor Finlay's son promised he would gladly consider housing
in this museum many of the souvenirs of his father such as the original yellow fever
manuscript, the original yellow fever mosquito vials, his father's microscope with
which all the work was done, and other souvenirs. For this museum I have collected
the original fever charts of most of the experimental cases in American soldiers.
We will also have available the original or a replica of the Congressional medal
presented to Reed and his associates and many other items of real interest to both
Cuban and American physicians and laymen.

The Mayo Clinic has promised me that they will be glad to help
contribute to this venture. Indeed, I know they would like to be in on it, and
if you could interest perhaps Rockefeller's committee on Pan-American relationships
or some other influential parties, I will indeed be very grateful.
